article.description:
Donatas Zavackas came out of a shooting slump
with 15 points and No. 7 Pittsburgh finally played a runaway game
after a succession of close ones, blowing out rival West Virginia
82-46 Wednesday night.
article.headline: Zavackas ends shooting slump in Panthers' win
article.linkText: Pitt finally wins easy one with rout of Mountaineers
article.story:
PITTSBURGH (AP) -- Donatas Zavackas came out of a shooting slump
with 15 points and No. 7 Pittsburgh finally played a runaway game
after a succession of close ones, blowing out rival West Virginia
82-46 Wednesday night.

	   The Panthers (17-3, 7-2 Big East) fell from No. 2 to 7 in the AP
poll while dropping road games against Syracuse and Notre Dame, but
they never were challenged by the smaller and less physical Mountaineers.

	   Pittsburgh's 36-point margin of victory was its largest in the
164-game rivalry, topping its 27-point win (92-65) last season in
the final game in Fitzgerald Field House.

	   Even with backcourt starters Brandin Knight and Julius Page
contributing little offensively in the first half, Pitt went on an
early 13-2 run to open up a 17-6 lead and West Virginia (12-9, 3-6)
never did threaten.

	   With Zavackas scoring from the outside and Chevy Troutman
constantly get free underneath for easy baskets, the Panthers
pushed the lead to 37-20 by outscoring West Virginia 16-4 over the
final five minutes of the first half.

	   All but three of Zavackas' points came in the first half in his
first double-digit outing in five games. Troutman added 13 points,
with Jaron Brown getting 11 and Page scoring 10.

	   The Panthers, perhaps relieved to not be playing a tight game
for a change, turned the backyard rivalry into a rout with a 17-0 run early in the second half that made it 56-25.

	   That allowed coach Ben Howland to make liberal use of his bench,
something he couldn't do in the road losses and two recent close
home victories over Georgetown (65-64) and Providence (68-61).

	   West Virginia, unable to get open looks from the outside or to
get the ball inside against Pitt's strong defense, scored only four
points over a 10-minute stretch as the Panthers opened up a 68-29
lead.

	   Drew Schifino, the former Pittsburgh-area high school star who
came into the game averaging 21.3, was held to six points in the
first half and 12 overall. No other West Virginia player scored in
double figures.

	   Pitt, 17-3 for the second straight season, won despite yet
another ineffective scoring effort from Knight, the Big East's
preseason player of the year. His only scoring came on a 3-pointer
with 12:32 remaining, the third time in six games he has been held
to 4 or fewer points.

	   Knight's average fell below 10 points, a season after the
third-team All-American averaged 15.5. With Knight battling the flu
and a sore ankle, freshman backup Carl Krauser was more effective,
coming off the bench for 12 points and four assists.

	   West Virginia lost its third in four games and its sixth in nine
games. The teams first played 98 years ago and the largest margin
of victory by either was a 40-point West Virginia win in 1966.

	   Pittsburgh improved to 13-0 in its first season at the Petersen
Events Center and has won four straight at home over West Virginia
_ the last two by a combined 63 points.
